A video that shows bodies of many kids is being circulated widely on WhatsApp groups in Kerala along with a message in Malayalam saying these bodies,  with their organs removed,  were found in a container in Tamil Nadu by the police.
FACT CHECK: Truth behind video of 'women' stripping at Delhi’s Signature Bridge
A 6-second-long video clip being circulated on social media shows Congress President Rahul Gandhi saying he would “change the direction of sunrise if the voters make him the prime minister”.

Photographs of Bollywood actor Kareena Kapoor Khan,  from the time she was actually pregnant,  are being shared on social media platforms with the claim of she being pregnant again  and with derogatory captions.

A black-and-white photo has made its re-entry to social media circles as that of Tipu Sultan's. The photo is not of Tipu Sultan,  and there never can be a photo of Sultan because a camera was invented three decades after the king's death.
Fake copies of The Washington Post newspaper were circulated for free to commuters outside Union Station and in front of White House.
FACT CHECK: Man carried horse on his back after it was bitten by a snake?
FACT CHECK: Were 1,000 trees felled to make helipad in Odisha ahead of PM Modi’s visit?

The claim is being made using a picture of Kumble with Prime Minister Narendra Modi. In the photo,  Modi and Kumble are shaking hands,  possibly right after the legendary leg-spinner gifted PM a bouquet.
FAKE ALERT: Fake news around Rahul Gandhi’s UAE visit
FAKE ALERT: Old video from China zoo spread to trigger tiger scare in Odisha
FACT CHECK: AAP tweets photo of Netherland's Erasmus Bridge as of Delhi's Signature Bridge

Photographs of a name board that was installed near the Sardar Vallabhai Patel statue inaugurated on October 31 with ‘Statue of Unity’ written in ten different languages,  including Spanish,  French,  Arabic,  Hindi,  Tamil etc. are going viral on social media.

A portion of a video from Rahul Gandhi's Karnataka rally,  where a supporter tossed a garland making it land perfectly around Gandhi's neck,  was shared by famous Urdu poet Rahat Indori claiming that the incident happened in Indore.

A video shot by Doordarshan News crew member Mormukut Sharma,  as the crew and the security personnel came under Maoist attack in Chhattisgarh's Dantewada district,  is being misunderstood and shared as the last video by Doordarshan cameraman Achutanand Sahu,  killed by Naxals.

Congress MP Shashi Tharoor,  while speaking at an event in Bengaluru,  quoted an unnamed RSS source as metaphorically saying  "Modi is like a scorpion sitting on a Shivling; you can't remove him with your hand and you cannot hit it with a chappal either". Here's everything you need to know about it

As per a tweet going viral on Twitter,  a man named Javed was arrested in Ranchi for using 10000 SIM cards to create fake Facebook IDs under brahmin names and campaign for NOTA (None of the above) option in elections.

Days before the inauguration of Sardar Vallabhai Patel's Statue of Unity,  the world's tallest statue,  a digitally-manipulated image -- with a homeless family placed in front of the statue -- is being circulated widely on social media platforms to amplify the voices of members of tribal communities who are calling for a boycott of the statue.

Over the last few days,  several news websites and Twitter accounts said that CBI Special Director Rakesh Asthana had given away Rs 20 crore from the Police Welfare Fund to the BJP election fund when he was posted as Surat police commissioner,  under the watch of then Gujarat CM Narendra Modi.

Reports of the death of an eight-year-old Muslim boy in Delhi’s Malviya Nagar area sparked debate online after many social media users gave it a communal angle saying the boy was lynched. What is the truth?

A video taken during a mock drill organised by Jharkhand Police in Khunti district in October 2017 is now being shared by many social media users saying it's a video of peaceful protesters being fired at by security forces.
A video going viral on social media accuses ‘Hindu Yuva Vahini’,  an outfit floated by Uttar Pradesh CM Yogi Adityanath,  of “humiliating and thrashing” a couple.

A graphic card claiming former CJI Dipak Misra is paralysed due to Lord Ayyappa’s wrath for Misra’s verdict allowing entry of women of all ages to the Sabarimala Temple,  are being shared along with a photo of late physicist Stephen Hawking.

Journalist Abhisar Sharma ‘investigated’ the video footage of the Amritsar train tragedy and claimed that the ‘top light’ of the Jalandhar-Amritsar DMU train was ‘non-functional’. Navjot Singh Sidhu made the same claim.
Many Indian Twitter users are claiming that Germany has banned consumption of meat at all official government functions.

Images and videos of a man hanging from a bridge are being circulated on social media to claim that the driver of the DMU train that was involved in the tragic accident in Amritsar has committed suicide.

Photos from 2017 of Muslims offering Alvida Namaz (the last Friday prayer on Ramzan) on railway tracks near the New Delhi Railway station at Achchan Mian Masjid is being shared to question if trains could be stopped for namaz,  why it cannot be halted for ‘Ravan Dahan’ during Dussehra celebrations.
A photograph of Congress President Rahul Gandhi is being widely circulated with a false claim that he offered namaz inside a Temple.
A video of Congress leader Ashok Gehlot talking at an AICC press conference in May this year is being circulated a second time on social media platforms and instant messaging platform WhatsApp.

Different verified Twitter handles of the Congress Party shared tweets saying PM Modi and the NDA government failed to do much when it comes to the cleaning of the Ganga river despite it being a major poll promise.

A fake quote attributed to top US industrialist and former chairman of CISCO Systems John Chambers is being circulated a lot. The quote reads, India's "impressive development" will cease to exist if Modi gets a second term as country's leader after next year's parliamentary election.

A two-year-old image from Bangladesh was shared by the official Twitter handle of Office of Congress MP Kamal Nath with a misleading claim to take a dig at Madhya Pradesh chief Minister Shivraj Singh Chauhan.
A Hindi newspaper clipping going viral on social media is attributing a controversial remark against people from Uttar Pradesh (UP) and Bihar to BJP leader Ramesh Bidhuri.
A misleading photo of RJD chief Lalu Prasad Yadav’s son Tej Pratap Yadav is being widely circulated with a claim that he received a doctorate from 'Takshsila University'.

A photo taken during a 2013 rally held in Haryana's Gohana,  addressed by Congress leader and then Haryana CM Bhupinder Singh Hooda,  is being shared widely with a claim that 25 lakh people attended Rahul Gandhi's Bikaner rally.

In two separate newspaper clippings that are being widely circulated on WhatsApp and social media platforms,  it is being wrongly claimed that PM Narendra Modi and Delhi Chief Minister Arvind Kejriwal committed rape many years ago.

A video of Kolkata's Ranaghat Junction railway station is being shared widely on social media platforms with a claim that people who moved to different parts of Gujarat from Uttar Pradesh,  Bihar and other states,  mostly to make a livelihood,  are feeling the state in fear of being attacked by locals.

Congress Party's official Twitter handle and Rahul Gandhi's official Twitter handle tweeted a video of a conversation between Union Minister Nitin Gadkari and actor Nana Patekar where Gadkari is talking about not being confident of winning elections,  and how politicians ignore public scrutiny of election promises.

A three-year-old news report with incorrect information is being recirculated by many prominent,  verified Twitter handles with huge following. This includes journalist Saba Naqvi,  Mahila Congress leader Lavanya Ballal, Pakistani columnist Arif Rafiq questioning the Uttar Pradesh (UP) government and tolerance of ‘Hindu’ religion.
A Facebook page by the name of ‘Yogi Sarkar’ has been at the forefront in spreading misinformation and rumours on social media platforms.

A video of a beach in Kerala’s Malappuram district is being circulated on WhatsApp and social media platforms with a claim that it is of Rama Setu - the bridge mentioned in the epic Ramayana and believed to be made for Lord Rama to cross the Indian Ocean and reach Ravana’s Lanka.

A WhatsApp video showing the world’s biggest flying bird -- Andean Condor -- is being circulated widely,  along with a message saying ‘Jatayu’ bird mentioned in the epic Ramayana was spotted in Karnataka.
A simple fact-check reveals that the image being shared is from AP and not UP and is being spread with inaccurate claims.

Among the stamps released by the Pakistan postal department in a series titled Atrocities in Indian-occupied Kashmir, is a photo of the members of a Kashmiri Pandit group clicked during a peaceful protest organised at Jantar Mantar to mark the 24th anniversary of the Kashmiri Pandit Exodus Day.

An impostor Twitter handle that posed to be the official handle of the Hindustan Aeronautics Limited became the talk of Indian Twitter after it responded to the statement issued by Defence Minister Nirmala Sitharaman on Rafale deal saying the deal under UPA fell through because HAL did not have the required capability to produce them.

Congress President Rahul Gandhi,  while talking at a rally in Madhya Pradeh's Chitrakoot,  said that the statue of Sardar Vallabhai Patel,  called the Statue of Unity,  is being 'made in China'. Is it true?

A photo showing women holding placards with ‘Modi chor’,  meaning ‘PM Modi is a thief’,  is digitally manipulated. Times Fact Check has found the original photo to be from the launch event of Pradhan Mantri Jan Arogya Yojana held by the Ministry of Health in Ranchi.

A video showing a boy with a severe injury on his neck,  and profusely bleeding,  is being shared with a claim that ‘Islamic terrorists’ cut the kid’s throat during a Muharram procession that happened in Gauri Bazar area of Uttar Pradesh’s Deoria district. This claim is false.

Pakistani journalist Hamid Mir tweeted a video showing a man being brutally beaten up by a few men suggesting that it is Indian Army soldiers torturing a Kashmiri youngster. This claim is false. Times Fact Check confirmed that the video is of a Pashtun man being tortured by Pakistani soldiers.

A digitally manipulated photo of BJP Delhi Spokesperson Tajinder Pal Singh Bagga wearing a T-shirt that says Prime Minister Narendra Modi is a ‘thief’ is being shared widely by many on social media platforms. The photo was tweeted by former JNUSU Vice-President Shehla Rashid and former Congress MLA Akhilesh Pratap Singh.
A Facebook page by the name of ‘Fekunama’,  as the name ironically suggests,  is a serial fake news peddler,  who is known for propagating misinformation on Facebook.

A year-old video is being circulated on WhatsApp and social media platforms with a claim that a kid who was being rushed to a hospital in an ambulance died due to traffic regulations imposed by Delhi Police for easy passage of BJP MP Manoj Tiwari.

A message that is going viral on social media these days is spreading misinformation about the world's largest government-funded healthcare programme - Ayushman Bharat - Pradhan Mantri Jan Arogya Yojana.

A digitally manipulated newspaper clipping with a fake quote on Kashmir attributed to Delhi CM Arvind Kejriwal is being circulated on social media platforms again. The same clipping had gone viral in 2016 and was busted by Navbharat Times then.

A Facebook user,  who according to his bio on the social network platform,  is a Congress Party worker,  shared an image of Rajasthan CM Vasundhara Raje and claimed that she got drunk while resting after the Rajasthan Gaurav Yatra event. The photo shared to make this claim is incomplete.
The video is being shared by some Twitter and Facebook users,  and many are attacking Kumar for purportedly hiding this “fact” from media and projecting himself as a “low-caste Hindu”.

Sarah Sanders,  White House Press Secretary,  in a statement that came in the form of  Twitter thread,  accused CNN journalist Jim Acosta of behaving inappropriately with a White House intern and announced that the suspension of his White House press pass.
FAKE ALERT: Tarek Fatah tweets doctored photo making false claim about madrassa teacher
The photo used in the tweet juxtaposes PM Modi’s image next to the woman,  with the text “Bahut hua naari par vaar,  abki baar Modi sarkaar”.
A video of Prime Minister Narendra Modi carrying a little girl in his arms to a dias and making her say,  “Rahul Gandhi Pappu hai”,  in front of a mike,  is being circulated on social media.

Photos of a man from Kerala,  clicked as part of a photoshoot,  are being circulated widely on social media platforms with a claim that the photos show Kerala Police's brutality on Sabarimala devotees.

A video showing many kids,  girls and boys,  in school uniform,  twerking and grinding,  is being shared widely on social media platforms. Most of the users sharing this video are holding ‘Convent education’ responsible for this. This video is from 2014 and is from Cuba.
The official Twitter handle of Bhartiya Janta Yuva Morcha (BJYM) accused the Youth Congress of “spreading fake news” by showing parts of Jammu and Kashmir (J&K) in Pakistan’s map.

A couple of photos of former Indian cricket-team captain MS Dhoni sitting at a petrol filling station are being circulated on social media platforms with a claim that he joined the Bharat bandh organised yesterday in protest against rising petrol prices. This is a false claim.

A message that is being circulated on WhatsApp groups in Kerala spreads misinformation about a tiger being on the loose in Kerala's Kalady town. People spreading this fake alert also send a video to support the claim

A Facebook page named Bhim Sena shared a video last week claiming it to be of ‘RSS beating Dalits in Tamil Nadu’ with an apparent intent to incite caste tensions. but the video is from years ago,  and not one shot in Kerala.

Prasenjit Das,  NSUI vice president of Tripura and a journalist as per his Twitter bio,  made a tweet that suggested that people of northeast India are participating in the Bharat bandh called by the opposition parties and are indulging in violence.

A message,  said to be from the Chief Superintendent of Police,  Indore,  warning people about a group of Rohingya Muslims roaming the city with weapons,  is being circulated on WhatsApp. Times Fact Check has confirmed that the rumour is false.

Parody news handles that deliberately try to mislead Twitter users are on a rise. These fake/parody accounts of media houses add to the growing problem of fake news and misinformation going viral,  and this cannot be overlooked by putting the onus on the social media users alone.

Details from a news article published in 2017 are being used by many publications,  including Scoop Whoop,  to write new reports claiming animals are dying in Kaziranga National Park due to floods in Assam.

A few Twitter users have been accusing Congress President Rahul Gandhi of sharing photos available on the internet as that from his Kailash Mansarovar Yatra. Times Fact Check investigated the photos shared by Gandhi to find that the accusations are false.

Fake news reports circulating on the Internet and social media claim that Aurangzeb once fought a war with China,  defeated it and took control of Hindu pilgrimage Kailash Mansarovar from the Chinese as a gift to Hindus of India.

Senior advocate Prashant Bhushan tweeted saying members of the Akhil Bhartiya Vidyarti Parishad attacked a professor in Gujarat's Kutch University,  suggesting that the incident happened in September. The incident is true but Bhushan's tweet is misleading.

A 10-year-old image of a violent mob stripping an Adivasi girl on the streets of Guwahati has been doing the rounds on social media again. This time,  only with the intention to defame Congress unit in the state of West Bengal.
Many social media users and pages that spread misinformation have been using two stills from Malayalam TV soap and claiming that ISIS terrorists killed Kerala IPS officer and her husband.
Fake claims that the Kerala government is spending the money they received in donations for Kerala flood relief on buying luxury cars for government employees are doing rounds on social media.

Screenshots and images from a two-year-old CCTV footage from Bihar are being circulated on social media and fake news websites to target the Bhartiya Janta Party (BJP) ahead of Rajasthan assembly elections this year.

A video of a beggar being beaten up by some men was being shared on social media with claims that Muslim men were caught on camera thrashing a Naga Sadhu,  Dehradun Police clarified that this claim is fake.

Many local websites have been found to be announcing recruitment rallies by the Indian Army to select candidates for the force. Assam Police tweeted an advisory on such fake recruitment posts yesterday.

Bahujan Samaj Party's social media influencer Devendra Jarariya recently shared a fake image on Twitter which claimed that ashes of former PM Atal Bihari Vajpayee are being sold on e-commerce website Amazon.

One of the biggest fake news peddler on Facebook is a page that goes by the name ‘Viral in India’. The page has close to a million followers. It regularly spreads misinformation on social media through posts with misinformation.

Messages claiming banks in the country will not be functional up to six days out of the first nine days in September are fake. Such messages are going viral on social media platforms and instant messaging applications like WhatsApp.

Fake claims of a proposed Bharat bandh on September 6,  organised by people belonging to General and OBC categories against reservation, are doing rounds on social media platforms and WhatsApp. Claims of Anna Hazare being a part of this protest against reservation are false.

Photos showing a Hindu woman tying a rakhi to a Muslim man and another one showing a severely injured woman are being shared together with a fake claim that the man,  said to be a local Congress leader from Uttar Pradesh's Gonda,  raped and brutally thrashed the woman a day after she tied him a rakhi.

A fake post doing rounds on social media claims that furnishing their Aadhaar cards was mandatory for all the children and women who Prime Minister Narendra Modi met on Raksha Bandhan day,  and only those who had their Aadhaar cards were allowed to tie rakhi on PM Modi’s wrist.
A fake Twitter handle impersonating sacked BSF jawan Tej Bahadur Yadav has been misleading its followers on the micro-blogging platform with anti-India tweets.

A Twitter account tweeted a video of a woman inaugurating a gym claiming it to be Karnataka Chief Minister HD Kumaraswamy's wife. The video is that of former Miss India Ankita Shorey and is from 2014.
A Facebook user,  who goes by the name Sreekumar Sasidharan Nair,  made a post claiming that union ministers and BJP MPs made a contribution of Rs 25 crore to the CMDRF.

A Facebook user,  who according to his bio on the social network platform,  is a Congress Party worker, shared an image of Rajasthan CM Vasundhara Raje and claimed that she got drunk while resting after the Rajasthan Gaurav Yatra event. The photo shared to make this claim is incomplete.

A video in which a woman and a few youngsters could be seen thrashing a policeman in uniform is being shared with a false claim that a group Muslims in Bareilly's Civil Lines area beat up the cop after he issued them a challan. This claim is false,  UP Police confirmed to Times Fact Check.
Hoardings and cutouts of Congress President Rahul Gandhi were put up in Madhya Pradesh ahead of his roadshow in Bhopal last Sunday,  greeting Rahul as a ‘Shiv Bhakt’ or a devotee of Lord Shiva.

Mohandas Pai tweeted an article published on BBC News Hub that listed Indian National Congress as one of the most corrupt political parties in the world. BBC News Hub is an impostor website and has nothing to do with BBC.
Modi’s Saifee mosque visit,  for many,  was a perfect opportunity to circulate photoshopped images and spread fake news.

Scamsters are sending text messages to people and misleading them into believing that these messages are from banks and the Income Tax Department even. Many people are falling for it and end up sharing personal details and bank account details.
